name: Ampulla
description: The hepatopancreatic ampulla (of Vater) is the dilation formed by the union of the pancreatic duct and common bile duct. The mucosa shows complex valvular folds.

features: Sphincter of Oddi (smooth muscle) surrounding the specific ducts
Transition to duodenal epithelium at the papilla
location: Wall of the 2nd part of the duodenum
Formed by junction of CBD and PD
function: Conduit for bile and pancreatic juice flow
Regulation of flow (via Sphincter of Oddi)
theory.examTips: Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction can cause biliary pain. Gallstones can impact here, causing both obstructive jaundice AND pancreatitis ('Gallstone Pancreatitis').

name: Ampulla of Vater
description: The Ampulla of Vater specifically refers to the dilated junction where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct enter the duodenum. Key features include the complex sphincter mechanism.

features: Dilation at junction of CBD and PD
Surrounded by Sphincter of Ampulla (part of Sphincter of Oddi)
Projects into duodenum as Major Duodenal Papilla
function: Mixing of bile and pancreatic enzymes
theory.examTips: Abraham Vater described this. It's a key landmark for ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography). Tumors here (Ampullary carcinoma) present early with painless jaundice due to duct obstruction.

name: Major Papilla
description: The Major Duodenal Papilla is the nipple-like projection of the ampulla into the duodenal lumen. It is covered by duodenal mucosa.

features: Covered by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells
Opening of the ampulla at its tip
Frenulum of the papilla (distal longitudinal fold)
function: Exit point for bile and pancreatic juice
Mechanical protection of the duct opening
theory.examTips: The Minor Duodenal Papilla (Accessory Pancreatic Duct opening) is located ~2cm proximal (superior) to the Major Papilla. Cannulation of the major papilla is the first step in ERCP.

name: Bile duct
description: Extrahepatic bile ducts are fibromuscular tubes lined by simple columnar epithelium. They transport bile from liver/gallbladder to the duodenum.

theory.examTips: Histologically looks simpler than ureter. Ureter has TRANSITIONAL epithelium and THICK muscle. Bile duct has COLUMNAR epithelium and THIN/SPARSE muscle. PSC (Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis) causes 'onion-skin' fibrosis around ducts.

name: Cystic Duct
description: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. Its mucosa forms spiral valve-like folds known as the Spiral Valves of Heister.

features: Connects gallbladder neck to Common Hepatic Duct
location: Between gallbladder neck and common hepatic duct
function: Bidirectional flow of bile (filling and emptying gallbladder)
Valves prevent collapse/kinking of the duct
theory.examTips: The 'Spiral Valves of Heister' are true anatomical valves but spiral FOLDS of mucosa containing smooth muscle. They keep the duct open so bile can flow in bidirectional manner.

name: Gallbladder
description: The gallbladder is a muscular sac storing and concentrating bile. Its wall has a characteristic simple columnar epithelium with apical microvilli, a muscularis propria, but NO muscularis mucosae or submucosa.

features: Mucosal folds which disappear upon distension
Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses: mucosal invaginations into muscle layer
Muscularis: irregular bundles of smooth muscle
location: Fossa on visceral surface of liver
function: Releases bile in response to CCK
theory.examTips: Lack of submucosa and muscularis mucosae = Gallbladder. Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses are predisposed to bacteria/stones (not normal, but common pathological finding). Epithelium concentrates bile 10-fold!

name: Liver
description: The liver is the largest internal organ, organized into hexagonal lobules. Hepatocytes radiate from a central vein, separated by sinusoids, with portal triads at the periphery.

features: Classic Lobule: Hexagon with central vein
Portal Triad (at angles): Portal vein branch, Hepatic artery branch, Bile duct
Hepatocytes: Polyhedral cells arranged in plates/cords
Sinusoids: Fenestrated capillaries lined by endothelium & Kupffer cells
Space of Disse: Between hepatocytes and endothelium
theory.examTips: Identify Portal Triad: Duct (cuboidal epithelium), Artery (thick wall), Vein (thin wall, large lumen). Blood flows Centripetally (Triad -> Central Vein). Bile flows Centrifugally (Hepatocytes -> Triad). Kupffer cells are liver macrophages.

name: Pancreas
description: The pancreas is a mixed exo-endocrine gland. The exocrine part consists of serous acini producing digestive enzymes. The endocrine part consists of Islets of Langerhans secreting hormones.

features: Exocrine: Serous acini with centroacinar cells (start of duct system)
Endocrine: Islets of Langerhans (pale staining clusters)
Intercalated ducts merge into interlobular ducts
location: Head in C-loop of duodenum, Tail touches spleen
function: Exocrine: Digestive enzymes (Trypsin, Lipase, Amylase) + Bicarbonate
theory.examTips: Centroacinar cells are UNIQUE to pancreas (pale nucleus in center of acinus). Parotid gland looks similar (serous) but HAS striated ducts and NO Islets. Pancreas HAS Islets and NO striated ducts. Islets = Pale islands in a sea of dark acini.
